channel.title: From Stata to R
channel.description: Recent content on From Stata to R

item.title: First contact with the data on R
item.description: Files used and organization of the project Import data Merge dataframes Descriptive Statistics Plots In this post, you will see how to import and treat data, make descriptive statistics and a few plots. However, I am still a recent user of R and I don’t know much about the optimal organization of files in a project (and many people explain it better than me online). Therefore, I will show you a personal method that is perhaps not the most effective but that works.

item.title: About
item.description: I am a French student doing a Master’s degree in economics and I’m sick of learning Stata to do econometrics. I love R and its flexibility and I think that students in university should learn R. However, R has a steeper learning curve than Stata. Therefore, this blog aims to facilitate the transition from Stata to R for students in economics. The content you can find on it may help students or professionals in other domains but the topics will be focused on economics.

item.title: Contact
item.description: You can contact me by email at etienne.bacher@orange.fr. You can write to me in English or in French if you prefer (I’m French too).

item.title: Why you should move from Stata to R
item.description: Before going into the details about studying economics with R, it makes sense to explain why you should use R compared to Stata. Before I start, please note that I have been using Stata occasionally for about a year whereas I spend much more time on R so I may forget some features that Stata has and that I am not aware of. However, I believe that what I have made with Stata corresponds to most Master students’ experiences, e.
